title: Saoirse Ronan gushes over finally getting to work with Meryl Streep on Little Women
text:
Saoirse Ronan has revealed she managed to 'keep her cool' working with Meryl Streep for the first time on Little Women.

The Brooklyn star, 25, had met Meryl, 70, a few times in the past and admitted on The Ellen DeGeneres Show that she was never able to hide her admiration for the three-time Oscar winner.

Although the pair have only one scene together in the film, where Saoirse plays Jo March and Meryl stars as Aunt March, the Irish actress made the most of it.

Interview: Saoirse Ronan, 25, has revealed she managed to 'keep her cool' working with Meryl Streep for the first time on Little Women

'It was my first time working with Meryl. I had met her at things and I could never be cool around her,' she said.

'We had one scene together. She had been doing this stuff with Flo [Florence Pugh] and Timothee [Chalamet].

'I was just like, it's going to be great to have this one scene with her and it was. I kept my cool because I had to, to make sure the scene was right. When they called cut, I was like, "Oh my God, I got to work with Meryl Streep."'

Discussing the film, which Saoirse has already received Oscar buzz for, she said: 'It's about this girl called Jo who's a writer and it's about her and her three sisters and her mother during the Civil War.

Starstruck: Saoirse had met Meryl, 70, a few times in the past and admitted on The Ellen DeGeneres Show that she was never able to hide her admiration for the actress

'It's very much about a person's autonomy and figuring out their own way and path in life.'

Saoirse was also given a scare by Ellen just in time for Halloween as both a ghost and a dark ghoul jumped out on her during the interview.

The actress remarked that she was expecting to be scared by the host as it is coming up to Halloween before someone jumped out of the table beside her.

Saoirse said: 'It was my first time working with Meryl. I had met her at things and I could never be cool around her. We had one scene together'

'I said to your crew before I came on, someone is going to jump out of something, someone is going to scare me because it's the day before Halloween,' she said.

Saoirse was still taken by surprise when the scare happened, saying: 'I wasn't expecting that!'

The Atonement star told how she divides her time between Dublin and London when she is not working and has yet to learn to drive, although she does not like the idea of having to drive in Los Angeles.

'Driving in LA scares me because at home we have like four cars on the road at any given time whereas here, you've got four lanes of traffic,' she said.

'It's a lot. I don't know why I drive actually, it's a terrible idea.'

Scare: Saoirse was also given a scare by Ellen just in time for Halloween as both a ghost and a dark ghoul jumped out on her during the interview

Surprise: The actress remarked that she was expecting to be scared by the host as it is coming up to Halloween before someone jumped out of the table beside her

Set in 1860s New England, Little Women follows the journey of four fearless sisters - Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence), Jo (Saoirse) and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) - as they each battle societal expectations.

Meryl transforms into the sisters' Aunt March, a wealthy widow who masks her naturally soft nature with a stern persona, while Laura portrays Marmee March, mother to the close-knit sisters.

The original novel, penned by Louisa May Allcott, was published in two volumes in 1868 and 1869 and has remained a popular tale.

In 1994, Winona Ryder starred in another remake as Josephine March, a young women who dreams of becoming a successful author.

Character: Saoirse plays Jo March in the film which she has already received Oscar buzz for

And in 2017, the BBC aired a miniseries version of the novel which featured Michael Gambon and Angela Lansbury.

Little Women is directed by screenwriter Greta, 35, who earned much critical acclaim last year for her work on the coming of age film Lady Bird, which also earned Saiorse an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress.

Emma's role was originally intended for Emma Stone, according to Variety, who reported that she was unable to commit to the role, as she was working on The Favourite at the time.

Little Women will be released in the UK on 26 December 2019.
